interface.name: CoreUtils
interface.summary: collection of basic file, shell and text manipulation utilities
interface.description: The GNU Core Utilities are the basic file, shell and text manipulation utilities of the GNU operating system. These are the core utilities which are expected to exist on every operating system.

group.langs: af be bg ca cs da de el es et eu fi fr ga gl hu it ja ko ms nb nl pl pt pt_BR ru sk sl sv tr zh_CN zh_TW

entry-point.summary: copy files and set attributes
entry-point.description: In the first three forms, copy SOURCE to DEST or multi- ple SOURCE(s) to the existing DIRECTORY, while setting permission modes and owner/group. In the 4th form, cre- ate all components of the given DIRECTORY(ies).

entry-point.summary: Basename: strip directory and suffix from filenames
entry-point.description: Print NAME with any leading directory components removed. If specified, also remove a trailing SUFFIX.

entry-point.summary: Cat: concatenate files and print on the standard output
entry-point.description: Concatenate FILE(s), or standard input, to standard out- put.

entry-point.summary: Chgrp: change group ownership
entry-point.description: Change the group of each FILE to GROUP. With --refer- ence, change the group of each FILE to that of RFILE.

entry-point.summary: Chmod: change file access permissions
entry-point.description: chmod changes the permissions of each given file accord- ing to mode, which can be either a symbolic representa- tion of changes to make, or an octal number representing the bit pattern for the new permissions.

entry-point.summary: Chown: change file owner and group
entry-point.description: chown changes the user and/or group ownership of each given file, according to its first non-option argument, which is interpreted as follows. If only a user name (or numeric user ID) is given, that user is made the owner of each given file, and the files' group is not changed. If the user name is followed by a colon or dot and a group name (or numeric group ID), with no spaces between them, the group ownership of the files is changed as well. If a colon or dot but no group name follows the user name, that user is made the owner of the files and the group of the files is changed to that user's login group. If the colon or dot and group are given, but the user name is omitted, only the group of the files is changed; in this case, chown performs the same function as chgrp.

entry-point.summary: Chroot: run command or interactive shell with special root directory
entry-point.description: Run COMMAND with root directory set to NEWROOT.

entry-point.summary: Cksum: checksum and count the bytes in a file
entry-point.description: Print CRC checksum and byte counts of each FILE.

entry-point.summary: Comm: compare two sorted files line by line
entry-point.description:
Compare sorted files FILE1 and FILE2 line by line.
With no options, produce three-column output. Column one contains lines unique to FILE1, column two contains lines unique to FILE2, and column three contains lines common to both files.

entry-point.summary: Cp: copy files and directories
entry-point.description: Copy SOURCE to DEST, or multiple SOURCE(s) to DIRECTORY.

entry-point.summary: Csplit: split a file into sections determined by context lines
entry-point.description: Output pieces of FILE separated by PATTERN(s) to files `xx01', `xx02', ..., and output byte counts of each piece to standard output.

entry-point.summary: Cut: remove sections from each line of files
entry-point.description: Print selected parts of lines from each FILE to standard output.

entry-point.summary: Date: print or set the system date and time
entry-point.description: Display the current time in the given FORMAT, or set the system date.

entry-point.summary: Dd: convert and copy a file
entry-point.description: Copy a file, converting and formatting according to the operands.

entry-point.summary: Df: report filesystem disk space usage
entry-point.description: df displays the amount of disk space available on the file system containing each file name argument. If no file name is given, the space available on all currently mounted file systems is shown. Disk space is shown in 1K blocks by default, unless the environment variable POSIXLY_CORRECT is set, in which case 512-byte blocks are used.

entry-point.summary: Dir: list directory contents
entry-point.description: List information about the FILEs (the current directory by default). Sort entries alphabetically if none of -cftuSUX nor --sort.

entry-point.summary: DirColors: color setup for ls
entry-point.description: Output commands to set the LS_COLORS environment vari- able.

entry-point.summary: Dirname: strip non-directory suffix from file name
entry-point.description: Print NAME with its trailing /component removed; if NAME contains no /'s, output `.' (meaning the current direc- tory).

entry-point.summary: Du: estimate file space usage
entry-point.description: Summarize disk usage of each FILE, recursively for directories.

entry-point.summary: Echo: display a line of text
entry-point.description: Echo the STRING(s) to standard output.

entry-point.summary: Env: run a program in a modified environment
entry-point.description: Set each NAME to VALUE in the environment and run COM- MAND.

entry-point.summary: Expand: convert tabs to spaces
entry-point.description: Convert tabs in each FILE to spaces, writing to standard output. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Expr: evaluate expressions
entry-point.description: Print the value of EXPRESSION to standard output. A blank line below separates increasing precedence groups.

entry-point.summary: Factor: factor numbers
entry-point.description: Print the prime factors of each NUMBER.

entry-point.summary: False: do nothing, unsuccessfully
entry-point.description: Exit with a status code indicating failure.

entry-point.summary: Fmt: simple optimal text formatter
entry-point.description: Reformat each paragraph in the FILE(s), writing to stan- dard output. If no FILE or if FILE is `-', read stan- dard input.

entry-point.summary: Fold: wrap each input line to fit in specified width
entry-point.description: Wrap input lines in each FILE (standard input by default), writing to standard output.

entry-point.summary: Date: print or set the system date and time
entry-point.description: Display the current time in the given FORMAT, or set the system date.

entry-point.summary: Echo: display a line of text
entry-point.description: Echo the STRING(s) to standard output.

entry-point.summary: Install: copy files and set attributes
entry-point.description: In the first three forms, copy SOURCE to DEST or multi- ple SOURCE(s) to the existing DIRECTORY, while setting permission modes and owner/group. In the 4th form, cre- ate all components of the given DIRECTORY(ies).

entry-point.summary: Ln: make links between files
entry-point.description: In the 1st form, create a link to TARGET with the name LINK_NAME. In the 2nd form, create a link to TARGET in the current directory. In the 3rd and 4th forms, create links to each TARGET in DIRECTORY. Create hard links by default, symbolic links with --symbolic. When creating hard links, each TARGET must exist.

entry-point.summary: Mkdir: make directories
entry-point.description: Create the DIRECTORY(ies), if they do not already exist.

entry-point.summary: Rmdir: remove empty directories
entry-point.description: Remove the DIRECTORY(ies), if they are empty.

entry-point.name: groups
entry-point.summary: groups - print the groups a user is in
entry-point.description: Same as id -Gn. If no USERNAME, use current process.

entry-point.summary: Sort: sort lines of text files
entry-point.description: Write sorted concatenation of all FILE(s) to standard output.

entry-point.summary: Head: output the first part of files
entry-point.description: Print the first 10 lines of each FILE to standard out- put. With more than one FILE, precede each with a header giving the file name. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Hostid: print the numeric identifier for the current host
entry-point.description: Print the numeric identifier (in hexadecimal) for the current host.

entry-point.summary: Hostname: set or print the name of the current host system
entry-point.description: Print or set the hostname of the current system.

entry-point.summary: Id: print real and effective UIDs and GIDs
entry-point.description: Print information for USERNAME, or the current user.

entry-point.summary: Join: join lines of two files on a common field
entry-point.description: For each pair of input lines with identical join fields, write a line to standard output. The default join field is the first, delimited by whitespace. When FILE1 or FILE2 (not both) is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Kill: send signals to processes, or list signals
entry-point.description: Send signals to processes, or list signals.

entry-point.summary: Link: call the link function to create a link to a file
entry-point.description: Call the link function to create a link named FILE2 to an existing FILE1.

entry-point.summary: Ln: make links between files
entry-point.description: In the 1st form, create a link to TARGET with the name LINK_NAME. In the 2nd form, create a link to TARGET in the current directory. In the 3rd and 4th forms, create links to each TARGET in DIRECTORY. Create hard links by default, symbolic links with --symbolic. When creating hard links, each TARGET must exist.

entry-point.summary: Logname: print user's login name
entry-point.description: Print the name of the current user.

entry-point.summary: Ls: list directory contents
entry-point.description: List information about the FILEs (the current directory by default). Sort entries alphabetically if none of -cftuSUX nor --sort.

entry-point.summary: Md5Sum: compute and check MD5 message digest
entry-point.description: Print or check MD5 (128-bit) checksums. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Mkdir: make directories
entry-point.description: Create the DIRECTORY(ies), if they do not already exist.

entry-point.summary: Mkfifo: make FIFOs (named pipes)
entry-point.description: Create named pipes (FIFOs) with the given NAMEs.

entry-point.summary: Mknod: make block or character special files
entry-point.description: Create the special file NAME of the given TYPE.

entry-point.summary: Mv: move (rename) files
entry-point.description: Rename SOURCE to DEST, or move SOURCE(s) to DIRECTORY.

entry-point.summary: Nice: run a program with modified scheduling priority
entry-point.description: Run COMMAND with an adjusted nice value, which affects the scheduling priority. With no COMMAND, print the current nice value. Nice values range from -20 (most favorable scheduling) to 19 (least favorable).

entry-point.summary: Nl: number lines of files
entry-point.description: Write each FILE to standard output, with line numbers added. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Nohup: run a command immune to hangups, with output to a non-tty
entry-point.description: Run COMMAND, ignoring hangup signals.

entry-point.summary: Od: dump files in octal and other formats
entry-point.description: Write an unambiguous representation, octal bytes by default, of FILE to standard output. With more than one FILE argument, concatenate them in the listed order to form the input. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Paste: merge lines of files
entry-point.description: Write lines consisting of the sequentially corresponding lines from each FILE, separated by TABs, to standard output. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Pathchk: check whether file names are valid or portable
entry-point.description: Diagnose unportable constructs in NAME.

entry-point.summary: Pinky: lightweight finger
entry-point.description: A lightweight `finger' program; print user information.

entry-point.summary: Pr: convert text files for printing
entry-point.description: Paginate or columnate FILE(s) for printing.

entry-point.summary: Printenv: print all or part of environment
entry-point.description: If no environment VARIABLE specified, print them all.

entry-point.summary: Printf: format and print data
entry-point.description: Print ARGUMENT(s) according to FORMAT.

entry-point.summary: Ptx: produce a permuted index of file contents
entry-point.description: Output a permuted index, including context, of the words in the input files.

entry-point.summary: Pwd: print name of current/working directory
entry-point.description: Print the full filename of the current working direc- tory.

entry-point.summary: Readlink: display value of a symbolic link
entry-point.description: Display value of a symbolic link on standard output.

entry-point.summary: Rm: remove files or directories
entry-point.description: rm removes each specified file. By default, it does not remove directories.

entry-point.summary: Rmdir: remove empty directories
entry-point.description: Remove the DIRECTORY(ies), if they are empty.

entry-point.summary: Seq: print a sequence of numbers
entry-point.description: Print numbers from FIRST to LAST, in steps of INCREMENT.

entry-point.summary: Setuidgid: run a command as a specified user
entry-point.description: Drop any supplemental groups, assume the user-ID and group-ID of the specified USERNAME, and run COMMAND with any specified ARGUMENTs. Exit with status 111 if unable to assume the required UID and GID. Otherwise, exit with the exit status of COMMAND. This program is useful only when run by root (UID=0).

entry-point.summary: Sha1sum: compute and check SHA1 message digest
entry-point.description: Print or check SHA1 (160-bit) checksums. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Shred: delete a file securely
entry-point.description: Overwrite the specified FILE(s) repeatedly, in order to make it harder for even very expensive hardware probing to recover the data.

entry-point.summary: Sleep: delay for a specified amount of time
entry-point.description: Pause for NUMBER seconds. SUFFIX may be `s' for seconds (the default), `m' for minutes, `h' for hours or `d' for days. Unlike most implementations that require NUMBER be an integer, here NUMBER may be an arbitrary floating point number.

entry-point.summary: Sort: sort lines of text files
entry-point.description: Write sorted concatenation of all FILE(s) to standard output.

entry-point.summary: Split: split a file into pieces
entry-point.description: Output fixed-size pieces of INPUT to PREFIXaa, PREFIXab, ...; default PREFIX is `x'. With no INPUT, or when INPUT is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Stat: display file or filesystem status
entry-point.description: Display file or file system status.

entry-point.summary: Stty: change and print terminal line settings
entry-point.description: Print or change terminal characteristics.

entry-point.summary: Su: run a shell with substitute user and group IDs
entry-point.description: Change the effective user id and group id to that of USER.

entry-point.summary: Sum: checksum and count the blocks in a file
entry-point.description: Print checksum and block counts for each FILE.

entry-point.summary: Sync: flush filesystem buffers
entry-point.description: Force changed blocks to disk, update the super block.

entry-point.summary: Tac: concatenate and print files in reverse
entry-point.description: Write each FILE to standard output, last line first. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Tail: output the last part of files
entry-point.description: Print the last 10 lines of each FILE to standard output. With more than one FILE, precede each with a header giv- ing the file name. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Tee: read from standard input and write to standard output and files
entry-point.description: Copy standard input to each FILE, and also to standard output.

entry-point.summary: Test: check file types and compare values
entry-point.description: Exit with the status determined by EXPRESSION.

entry-point.summary: Touch: change file timestamps
entry-point.description: Update the access and modification times of each FILE to the current time.

entry-point.summary: Tr: translate or delete characters
entry-point.description: Translate, squeeze, and/or delete characters from stan- dard input, writing to standard output.

entry-point.summary: True: do nothing, successfully
entry-point.description: Exit with a status code indicating success.

entry-point.summary: Tsort: perform topological sort
entry-point.description: Write totally ordered list consistent with the partial ordering in FILE. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Tty: print the file name of the terminal connected to standard input
entry-point.description: Print the file name of the terminal connected to stan- dard input.

entry-point.summary: Uname: print system information
entry-point.description: Print certain system information. With no OPTION, same as -s.

entry-point.summary: Unexpand: convert spaces to tabs
entry-point.description: Convert blanks in each FILE to tabs, writing to standard output. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Uniq: remove duplicate lines from a sorted file
entry-point.description: Discard all but one of successive identical lines from INPUT (or standard input), writing to OUTPUT (or stan- dard output).

entry-point.summary: Unlink: call the unlink function to remove the specified file
entry-point.description: Call the unlink function to remove the specified FILE.

entry-point.summary: Uptime: tell how long the system has been running
entry-point.description: Print the current time, the length of time the system has been up, the number of users on the system, and the average number of jobs in the run queue over the last 1, 5 and 15 minutes. If FILE is not specified, use /var/run/utmp. /var/log/wtmp as FILE is common.

entry-point.summary: Users: print the user names of users currently logged in to the current host
entry-point.description: Output who is currently logged in according to FILE. If FILE is not specified, use /var/run/utmp. /var/log/wtmp as FILE is common.

entry-point.summary: Vdir: list directory contents
entry-point.description: List information about the FILEs (the current directory by default). Sort entries alphabetically if none of -cftuSUX nor --sort.

entry-point.summary: Wc: print the number of bytes, words, and lines in files
entry-point.description: Print newline, word, and byte counts for each FILE, and a total line if more than one FILE is specified. With no FILE, or when FILE is -, read standard input.

entry-point.summary: Who: show who is logged on
Whoami: print effective userid
entry-point.description: Print the user name associated with the current effec- tive user id. Same as id -un.

entry-point.summary: Yes: output a string repeatedly until killed
entry-point.description: Repeatedly output a line with all specified STRING(s), or `y'.

entry-point.summary: [: test expression
entry-point.description: Exit with the status determined by EXPRESSION.
